comments.author: DubemIfedigbo001
comments.body: Quote from: bSpend on January 22, 2025, 07:51:33 PMWho else can relate with the information on the image below??Nothing serious anyway, but I just find it amazing that someone out there actually does experience this same stuff I experience at times üòÅ..It depends on when you lump summed. If you lump sum during the bear cycle, then you should be having the first image. In DCA you buy both the lows and the highs thereby smoothening the effect of volatility on your investment. The first chart has no representation of the volatile nature of Bitcoin across your DCA, there should be some downward and upward movement of the chart during your investment moments and then another line that attempt a straight line to provide a smoothening effect on your investments.Another consideration is the supposed length of your investment. If you intend to go for a longer period of time, then you don't have a problem lump summing, but I'll advise from experience that you should divide the bulk money into three, lump sum with a part, use the second party to follow up your investment with DCA and keep the third part to buy the dip and Hold.

comments.author: Free Market Capitalist
comments.body: I can't.These charts are typical of a novice retail investor, who is typically motivated to invest when the price goes up and when the price goes down does not invest or even worse, sells. Those of us who have been doing this for years know that it is the opposite, doing DCA implies forgetting about the ups and downs, buying regularly. And if you want to contribute a separate lump sum (if you are already doing DCA), better in a market downturn. On the other hand, if you are starting to think about investing now and you have a lump sum it is best to buy right now regardless of the price (as long as you believe in the great future of bitcoin in the long term), because you can not time the market, and it is better time in the market.

comments.author: Darker45
comments.body: That's why DCA is better than lump sum. If the price falls after you make your purchase, then your next purchase might be cheaper. If the price rises after your purchase, then your earlier purchase is already in profit, although you will be buying at a more expensive price after that. However, it doesn't mean that lump sum is a strategy everybody should avoid at all cost. The point, after all, in Bitcoin investment is to hodl. It's designed as a long-term investment. So, it matters a little that you bought at $100,000 and not $95,000 when the price has already hit $300,000 or $600,000 or $1 million.

comments.author: Davidvictorson
comments.body: I think the principles of DCA is specific to individual's understanding of it and how comfortable and confident they feel about it. You can follow the general principle of buy low and sell high, you can also follow the lump sum method. And finally follow the buy small portions consistently forgetting which of the market conditions you are in. It is about you and your goals. In my estimation, no one is better than the other and it is not a one-size-fits all approach. It is the out outcome of doing your own research that you should follow and if it doesn't work for you as much as you thought it would, you can change it to the one that works better for you.

comments.author: Smartprofit
comments.body: In my opinion, investing in Bitcoin (like any other human activity) requires motivation. You need to come up with your own motivation. Since we are talking about investments, it is useful to imagine at what price you will sell Bitcoin in the future. For example, you believe that sooner or later the price of Bitcoin will reach 1 million US dollars. At this price, you will be ready to sell your coins. Now you have the motivation to buy Bitcoin every month for a certain amount. You do not care what the purchase price is. The only thing you care about now is how many coins you will manage to accumulate before the price reaches the level you need.
